One can also prove analytically that the slope of the turnover-rate-employer-concentration curve is increasing in the job-finding rate and separation rate using Equation (5), namely $\partial^{2}\overline{{m}}/\partial\sigma_{2}\partial\lambda>0$ and $\partial^{2}\overline{{m}}/\partial\sigma_{2}\partial\delta>0$ This translates to the smaller (less negative) slope in Figure B.1.  

### B.2 Full Model Economy  

We describe the full model in Section 5 in more detail. Time is continuous. There is a continuum of ex ante homogeneous workers and $J$ sectors. In each sector, there are a finite number of infinitely lived firms, $i=1,...,M_{j},$ that differ in the firm-specific productivity $\{z_{i}\}_{i=1,\dots,M_{j}}$ . The notion ${}^{\prime\prime}\mathrm{firm}^{\prime\prime}$ here is tied to the pre-determined vector of productivity. While the worker-firm pair could dissolve, the probability that a worker meets with firm $i$ stays the same in the stationary equilibrium. Both firms and workers are risk-neutral with subjective discount rate $\rho$  

Unemployed workers receive unemployment benefit $b$ and meet firm $i$ With probability $\lambda(z_{i})$ . Upon receiving an offer from a firm, the worker and the firm determine the wage contract sequentially by mutual agreement as in Postel-Vinay and Robin (2002). Workers can renegotiate upon receiving an outside offer. The current and the poaching firm Bertrand-compete for the worker.  

The outside offer can come from other firms in the same sector or employers in different sectors. For the former, the arrival rate of offers is dictated by $\{\lambda(z_{i})\}$ . Because the number of firms is finite, the fact that workers do not receive offers from the current employer has a non-trivial impact on the probability that they receive outside offers. Outside the worker's sector, firms could poach the worker, but the poaching rate is affected by the probability of switching $\{\pi_{j\to k}\}$ between sector $j$ and $k$ . Besides endogenous worker turnovers through poaching and job-finding, there are also exogenous turnovers through separation at the rate $\delta_{s}$ and labor market exit at the rate $\delta_{d}$ . New workers enter the labor market at the rate $\delta_{d}$ to keep the measure of workers constant.  

Workers can learn on the job. In particular, an employed worker start at a firm with firm-specific human capital $\boldsymbol{x}_{t=0}=\underline{{\boldsymbol{x}}}(\boldsymbol{z})$ which evolves according to  

$$
d x_{t}=\mu(x,z)d t+\sigma(x,z)d W_{t}
$$  

Equation (B.1) implies that tenure affects workers' productivity. As workers' skills grow over time, their output also changes. However, the skill accumulation is not deterministic, as it is subject to random shocks given by the Brownian motion process $\{W_{t}\}$ . For simplicity, we assume that workers' firm-specific human capital "resets" if they experience labor market turnovers. This assumption implies two things: 1) If a worker switch to another employer, the worker's firm-specific productivity starts at $\underline{{x}}(z)$ for that employer; 2) The worker does not retain the firm-specific human capital even if the worker is employed at the same firm in the future.  

The first implication resonates with the notion that firm-specific human capitals differ from general human capitals (e.g., Acemoglu and Pischke, 1999). The second implication is stronger, but we note that when a worker is employed at the same employer repeatedly, the worker either was employed in another firm or unemployed. In both cases, the worker could spend sufficient time away from the employer that the firm-specific human capital has depreciated. Our assumption amounts to the extreme case that the depreciation rate is infinity.  

Let us use one example to further illustrate what the assumption means. Suppose a retail worker works at Walmart first, switches to Target, and jumps back to Walmart. The worker's general knowledge of retail industry is retained. However, while the worker spends time away from Walmart, the store arrangement or item prices could have changed at Walmart, so that the worker needs to learn them even with past experience.  

The initial human capital $\underline{{x}}(z)$ corresponds to hiring technology. As is clear later in the section, workers' output decreases if the firm-specific human capital is further below the firm's productivity $z$ , which creates switching incentives. On the other hand, if the initial human capital is closer to the firm's productivity, the worker and the firm form a good match in the sense that the output and hence the joint surplus is high, in which case the worker is hard to poach. Hence, an exogenous increase in the initial human capital can be interpreted as an improvement in the hiring technology.  

Let the joint match surplus for a worker with firm-specific human capital $x$ at firm $z$ in sector $j$ be $S(x,z,j)$ . Bertrand competition implies that the share of surplus allocated to the worker is endogenous. For example, suppose the initial wage contract is $W$ . When the worker is poached by another employer with productivity $z^{\prime}$ in sector $k,$ theworker stays if $S(x,z,j)\geqslant S(\underline{{x}},z^{\prime},k)$ and moves to the poacher otherwise. In both cases, the worker receives a new wage contract $W^{\prime}=\operatorname*{min}\left\{S(x,z,j),\operatorname*{max}\left\{S(\underline{{x}},z^{\prime},k),W\right\}\right\}$ . That is, the worker's new wage contract has a value equal to the joint surplus at the poacher if the worker stays or the joint surplus at the previous employer if the worker leaves.  

Denote the worker's share of surplus by $\eta,$ given by  

$$
\eta=\frac{S(\underline{{x}},z^{\prime},k)-U}{S(x,z,j)-U}
$$  

where $U$ is the value of unemployment. We follow Lise and Postel-Vinay (2020) and assume that this share is constant when the worker does not receive outside offers.

### B.5 A Shock to Employer Concentration  

We impose a shock to the employer concentration so that the turnover rate declines by $5\%$ Specifically, for each industry, we redistribute the vacancies to the firm with the largest measure of vacancies by decreasing the vacancy shares of other firms evenly. The $5\%$ decline in the turnover rate is associated with a $1.1\%$ decline in wages. Because Schubert et al. (2021) estimate that the employer concentration shock would decrease realized wages by $3\%$ , we calculate that $40\%$ of the decline is accounted for through the turnover channel.  

### B.6 Industry-Specific Minimum Wages  

Two observations motivate our policy analysis of industry-specific minimum wages. First, the effects of employer concentration on the turnover rate and wages are heterogeneous by industry. Second, Liu (2022b) show that a uniform minimum wage would disincentivize mobility by compressing wages.  

We hence consider setting minimum wages such that the lower-bounds on the workers' share of surplus Equation (B.2) need to implement the value of the least productive firms in each sector, where the dispersion comes from industry-specific productivity. But why does this imbalance in power exist? If workers cannot seamlessly move between jobs, they cannot respond to a marginally better employment option becoming available, or a worsening in the conditions of their current job. This may occur due to job search frictions (not knowing all options that are available, as in Pissarides, 2011; Bhuller et al., 2023), mobility frictions (an inability to move across occupations or geographies, as in Redding and Rossi-Hansberg, 2017; Heise and Porzio, 2021), contractual limitations (preventing a switch to a competitor, as in Starr et al., 2019), or simply a lack of alternatives (perhaps there is a single local employer due to barriers to entry, maybe due to job differentiation', as in Azar et al., 2022a). When employees face limited outside options in the labour market, frms with market power face upward-sloping labour supply functions, instead of the infinitely elastic labour supply that would prevail in the mythical perfectly competitive labour market. In this article, we survey how competition agencies have approached labour market power to date, what the latest empirical evidence tells us, and finish with some open questions for further research. We argue that, while certain types of labour market power are straightforwardly addressed with existing tools, others present unknown and often significant trade-offs for competition agencies. We summarize new empirical evidence to inform these trade-offs for the UK from a recent report by the UK Competition and Markets Authority (CMA, 2024). Across a variety of data sources and methodologies, labour market power in the UK does not seem to have increased in recent decades, in contrast to US trends. This underscores the importance of country-specific evidence. However, labour market power does not affect all labour markets and workers equally. Some markets are highly concentrated and, for workers in them, there are real costs to pay. Labour market power also interacts with, and is influenced by, other labour market policies and factors, from minimum wage policies to the prevailing employment law. This has two implications: first, analogies from product markets do not always carry over very well. Second, other policy-makers besides competition agencies may have access to better (or at least complementary) tools. We conclude with a series of open questions for researchers working on labour market power. These questions fall into four categories: theoretical, empirical, legal, and normative. Progress in these areas would enable a better understanding of the options and trade-offs competition agencies face with respect to labour market power. The rest of the article is structured as follows. Section I outlines what actions competition agencies worldwide have recently taken in this space. Section II summarizes the state of our knowledge on labour market power, with particular attention to the UK. Section Ill reviews the evidence on worker and wider outcomes. Section IV takes stock of what these trends mean for policy-makers, and a final section V lays out the important questions that remain unanswered. ### I. Competition enforcement in labour markets: tools and recent activity Competition policy enforcement with respect to labour market power currently broadly falls into three categories: respectively, the treatment of illegal practices such as wage fixing and no-poach agreements, guidance for firms (for instance, on solo self-employed workers and restrictive covenants), and, for a few agencies, labour market theories of harm in merger cases. Figure 1, based on the authors’ calculations, summarizes enforcement activities in this area. Three points stand out. First, the total number of enforcement actions with a labour market element has increased sixfold in the past 10 years. Second, wage-fixing and no-poach cases have accounted for most enforcement work in this area. Third, US competition authorities have been responsible for the largest share of cases to date. Finally, the new FTC/US DoJ Horizontal Merger Guidelines (US Department of Justice and Federal Trade Commission, 2023) explicitly state that agencies may intervene in merger cases on labour market grounds, regardless of the impact on product markets. In practice, US agencies have pursued three merger cases at least in part due to labour market concerns: the 2022 proposed takeover of publishing house Simon & Schuster by rival Penguin Random House22 and, more recently, the 2024 merger between supermarket chains Albertsons and Kroger23 and Tapestry's attempted acquisition of Capri, with implications in the luxury handbag market.24 There are also many examples of recent policy-maker interest in encouraging, raising, or preserving competition in labour markets beyond competition agencies. In 2021, the White House affrmed its commitment with an executive order ‘to enforce the antitrust laws to combat the excessive concentration of industry, the abuses of market power, and the harmful effects of monopoly and monopsony—-especially as these issues arise in labor markets'.25s This new prominence of labour market concerns reflcts the growing intellectual influence of the wider New Brandeis antitrust movement that has shifted thinking within US institutions such as the FTC and the DoJ, and in other countries. Neo-Brandeisians propose a wider focus for antitrust to promote competition beyond consumer welfare, to include welfare of individuals as citizens and workers. While a wider assessment of neo-Brandeisian antitrust in areas beyond labour markets is beyond the scope of this paper, we note the existence of a burgeoning research agenda taking a wider lens on competition economics to include these potential effects beyond consumer surplus (Cowgill et al., 2021; Deb et al., 2022; Berger et al., 2022). ### Il. How pervasive, and how damaging, is labour market power? Evidence of rising market power in output markets has provoked renewed concern that such trends may also be present in the labour market. In some ways, analysis of labour market power is analogous to that in output markets. Welfare analysis in a simple monopsony model is effectively a mirror image of the monopoly case. Yet there are some key differences, not least of all that labour markets are two-sided matching markets, involving search, contracts, heterogeneity of many forms, and bargaining. There is mounting evidence that wage markdowns (an estimate of the difference between the revenue contribution and the wage of the marginal worker in each firm) in the US over the last 20-25 years have risen steeply (Khan and Metaxoglou, 2021; Yeh et al., 2022; Kirov and Traina, 2023). This suggests that workers are taking home a smaller share of their marginal revenue product of labour in the US.26 This literature also sheds light on which frms can extract a greater share of worker surplus. There is some evidence that bigger firms may set higher markdowns, despite the well-documented large-firm wage premium (Amodio et al., 2022; Yeh et al., 2022). Larger firms are generally more productive, so could on average pay higher wages and yet still reduce the share of their marginal product that workers earn. However, Kirov and Traina (2023) do not find that this positive relationship between markdowns and frm size holds across a sample of US manufacturing firms. Researchers also study labour market concentration as a proxy for labour market power. US employer concentration declined sharply in the early 1980s but has since steadily climbed back to the level of the late 1970s (Rinz, 2022; Yeh et al., 2022). These results hold at the national level, but there is some debate about both the results and interpretation (Lipsius, 2018; Eeckhout, 2020). For one thing, while concentration is a reasonable proxy for market power in some popular models of competition such as Cournot, that is not always the case (Syverson, 2019; Eeckhout, 2020). Furthermore, we may observe diverging trends in local and national concentration simply due to demographic changes (Eeckhout, 2020). In fact, Rinz (2022) finds such divergence between local and national concentration trends for US labour markets, and Rossi-Hansberg et al. (2021) for US product markets. The authors argue that large firms like Walmart have entered many local markets, which lowers local concentration but raises national concentration. Finally, it is important to be clear whether measures of national labour market concentration measure that faced by the average worker, or the concentration in the average labour market. There is strong evidence that higher labour market concentration is negatively correlated with wages across many countries (Azar et al., 2020; Marinescu et al., 2021; Azar et al., $2022b$ ; Bassanini et al., 2023; Handwerker and Dey, 2024; Thoresson, 2024). However, a causal relationship is tricky to show definitively, as other factors like the distribution of frm productivity could drive both labour market concentration and average wages in a local labourmarket. Labour market power has three potential effects: it may suppress wages, raise prices, and introduce aggregate inefficiency. Firms with market power in the labour market can lower wages below the revenue provided by an additional worker. In an oligopsony framework, frms achieve this by reducing labour demand, moving down their upwards-sloping labour supply curve, therefore reducing labour input and producing less output. This lower output is associated with higher prices, as long as demand for a firm's output is not perfectly elastic. Labour market power is an additional wedge (alongside, for example, product market power or adjustment costs), which introduces inefficiency away from the theoretical allocative benchmark. It reduces firm size and the number of firms in many settings, leading to less intense competition (e.g. Deb et al., 2022). The impact is heterogeneous—more productive firms may have larger markdowns (e.g. Berger et al., 2022), leading to misallocation across firms. Labour market power thus slows down the competitive process across the economy. In a recently published report (CMA, 2024), the CMA used a variety of data sources and approaches to measure labour market power in the UK. The report centred on four key empirical findings. First, UK wage markdowns have been constant or slightly falling since 2008. Second, labour market concentration steadily declined from 2002 before rising briefly and sharply in the pandemic. Third, other labour market institutions also matter for labour market power. For instance, restrictive covenants are common across industries and throughout the income distribution and likely affect worker mobility. Fourth, individual earnings are negatively related to employer concentration, though this relationship disappears in the presence of collective bargaining agreements. Wage markdowns are equivalent to price markups but describe market power in labour markets rather than output markets. Markdowns tell us how much the average worker earns out of their marginal contribution to a firm's sales. Formally, they are defined as the ratio of the marginal revenue of labour to the marginal cost of labour (that is, the wage). Measuring the marginal revenue of labour is difficult, so the CMA report follows an established literature (Dobbelaere and Mairesse, 2013; Morlacco, 2019; Yeh et al., 2022), which estimates market power in product markets using two distinct inputs (labour and intermediate inputs) and takes the ratio of these two to back-out the market power in the labour market. This approach assumes that the market for intermediate inputs is competitive, though this assumption is controversial. As we show later in this article, joint market power in labour and input markets further complicates the picture. A nice feature of markdowns is that they provide a summary measure of the balance of power between workers and frms. Many factors may affect the markdown, from workers’ outside options, to collective bargaining, occupational licensing, and unemployment benefits. The markdown therefore summarizes information on many features of the labour market, such as tightness and regulation, and reflects the two-sided nature of labour markets. Figure 2 shows the evolution of the average wage markdown for the UK market economy. Wage markdowns increased slightly from 2008 to 2010, then decreased again. Overall, they have decreased slightly over the last 15 years. The levels in the chart have been standardized to make comparison of the trends easier. Figure 2 suggests that workers are taking home a larger share of their contribution to their employer's sales. The level of the markdown depends on the methods employed, but the report finds that employers capture between 15 and 45 per cent of the marginal contribution of workers. Of course, other labour market frictions or aspects of the employment relationship (such as which party carries the risk) will also influence the wage markdown. The CMA report also estimates labour market concentration, as measured by the employment Herfindahl Hirschman Index (HHI). The employment HHI is defined as the sum of squared employment shares within a labour market. Labour markets are defined at the Travel to Work Area (TTWA) by 3-digit Standard Occupational Classification (SOC). Here, we highlight two aspects that have attracted the interest of competition agencies: solo self-employed workers (often referred to as 'gig’ workers in the context of digital labour platforms) and the use of restrictive covenants (that is employment contract clauses that restrict the mobility of workers). Solo self-employed workers have been a focus for competition authorities since in a legal sense they are undertakings transacting with other undertakings (whether via a platform or otherwise), but from an economic point of view may be closer to workers transacting with an employer. While the former is usually a case for competition law enforcement, the latter in many countries would fall under employment laws instead. Restrictive covenants similarly are typically a matter of employment law, but might nonetheless have implications for how businesses compete, by making it harder for some companies to hire the right employees. The report uses individual-level survey data to measure the prevalence of gig workers in the UK economy. Gig workers are defined as anyone who sells their labour services via digital platforms. This is a narrower definition than wider casual or temporary work. Figure 5 shows that a small but growing part of the UK economy is in gig work. About 4 per cent of workers are gig workers, compared to closer to 10-12 per cent in wider temporary and casual work. Gig workers often work acros multiple jobs, within and outside the gig economy, and tend to combine gig earnings with other sources of income. The fraction of gig workers who work multiple jobs has been increasing over time. The increasing number of gig workers competing for tasks from a small number of platforms suggests that gig workers may not have much bargaining power relative to their employers, but more evidence is needed on this point. The extent to which gig workers are caught by competition law rules against coordination is a live issue in competition policy. The economic substance of the labour relationship matters here, not necessarily the precise contractual arrangements or the employment law position. For example, in September 2022, the European Commission adopted guidelines30 which clarify that EU competition law does not apply to solo self-employed people that are in a situation comparable to workers. These include those who provide services exclusively or predominantly to one undertaking; work side-by-side with workers; and provide services to or through a digital labour platform. The European Commission further clarified that it will not enforce EU competition rules against collective agreements made by solo self-employed individuals who are in a weak negotiating position against economically stronger companies. Whether non-competes on balance harm or help economic growth is an empirical question. Evidence from US state-level variation in legal rules (Johnson et al., 2023), from a ban on non-competes for low-wage workers in Oregon (Lipsitz and Starr, 2021) and a legislative change in California (Kang and Fleming, 2020) suggests that non-competes are indeed associated with less worker mobility and lower wages, and a shift in economic activity away from startups and towards incumbent frms. To the extent that they prevent reallocation towards startups, we may be concerned that non-competes therefore slow down the introduction of new ideas and processes into the economy. The CMA report found that many workers reported they had passed on an opportunity at a competitor or refrained from starting their own business because of their non-compete. ### Ill. What does labour market power mean for workers and the economy? Competition authorities are increasingly concerned with labour market power. Implicit in this concern is the assumption that workers, consumers, and the wider economy are harmed by it. This section shows that the evidence strongly suggests that worker outcomes are worse under labour market power. More widely, falling business dynamism and labour reallocation rates are at least consistent with rising aggregate labour market frictions. However, empirical evidence on the impact of labour market power on consumers is still thin on the ground. The link between labour market concentration and worker outcomes is well-established. Theoretically, firms use labour market power by reducing the labour they hire (in a monopsony model; Manning, 2021) or exploiting search frictions (Manning, 2011; Gottfries and Jarosch, 2023). Both channels allow them to lower the wage offered toworkers. Consistent with the theory, a large literature finds that concentration lowers workers’ wages. Most of this evidence is focused on the Us (for instance, Azar et al., 2020; Azar et al., $2022b$ ; Benmelech et al., 2022; Rinz, 2022; Handwerker and Dey, 2024). Abel et al. (2018) show a similar relationship holds for the UK. This literature is often criticized as not measuring the causal effect of concentration on wages since concentration and wages are both determined at the same time by decisions of workers and firms. The CMA report follows this literature, while noting the concerns about causality. It estimates worker-level wage-concentration regressions, with labour markets defined as the intersection of TTWA and 3-digit SOC. Linking employee data to employer data allows for a rich set of controls, although the report falls short of dealing with causality concerns in a systematic way (for instance, in the spirit of Azar et al., 2022a). The report finds that UK wages and labour market concentration are negatively correlated: the higher labour market concentration, the lower worker wages are on average. This relationship is robust to the inclusion of worker, firm, region, and time-specific controls. Figure 8 shows the relationship between wages and labour market concentration after removing the influence of these other variables: this allows us to compare workers on a more like-for-like basis. To reduce statistical noise, observations have been grouped into bins? based on the degree of concentration, and bin averages plotted instead. The relationship between wages and concentration is negative, statistically significant, and stable across different sets of control variables. While labour market concentration has not increased overall, in concentrated labour markets wages of comparable workers are lower than in less concentrated labour markets. The magnitude of the wage-concentration relationship is also economically significant. On average, and holding other worker, frm, and labour market characteristics constant, going from the bottom quartile to the top quartile of concentration is associated with 2 per cent lower wages. For a move from the bottom decile to the top decile wages are on average 4 per cent lower. However, as discussed below, there is some evidence that the magnitude of this effect has declined over time. When labour market power on the employer side is balanced by market power on the employee side, this negative relationship disappears. For a worker covered by a collective bargaining agreement, the negative association between wages and labour market concentration becomes quantitatively small and statistically insignificant.31 Finally, when estimating the wage-concentration relationship on a year-by-year basis, the report finds that the wage penalty has been decreasing over the last two decades for the UK. Figure 9 shows that while the elasticity of the wage with respect to concentration stood at $-0.04$ in 2002, in 2021 it had fallen to $-0.01$ andbecomestatistically indistinguishable from zero. Labour market concentration might also be related to other labour market outcomes, such as the number of hours worked, the unemployment rate, and the rate at which workers change jobs and employers. When workers have fewer outside options, they might, for instance, not be able to work as many hours as they would like. Figure 10 plots our coefficients for the elasticity of hours worked with respect to labour market concentration, for increasing sets of controls. The report finds an elasticityof about $-0.004$ for our baseline regression. This is consistent with a monopsony explanation of labour market power: to reduce wages, employers demand less labour. As a result, both equilibrium wages and hours are lower than they would be if the labour market were competitive. Labour market concentration and labour market institutions also interact in complex ways. For instance, labour market power may change the standard logic regarding negative labour supply effects of minimum wage policies. The argument goes as follows: in imperfectly competitive labour markets, labour supply curves are upwardssloping, frms must raise wages to hire more workers. They will hire up to the point that the marginal cost (the wage) equals the revenue provided by the marginal worker. Firms will pay below the marginal product of labour by restricting labour demand to maximize profits. However, a minimum wage creates a flat labour supply curve which kinks upwards only when the original supply curve is above the wage floor. This flat labour supply curve disincentivizes firms from under-hiring as they cannot benefit from lowering wages by hiring less. In this framework, a minimum wage can raise employment. Azar et al. (2023) argue that in concentrated US labour markets minimum wage policies may indeed increase employment. Similar results are found independently by Wiltshire et al.(2024). The CMA report finds comparable results for the UK. Workers who earn the National Minimum Wage work fewer hours and, similarly, workers in more concentrated labour markets work fewer hours. However, because the interaction term is positive, the joint effect is lower than the sum of the two: the National Minimum Wage therefore lowers hours worked less in more concentrated labour markets. Figure 11 shows a scatterplot of the relationship between total employment and the share of workers covered by the National Minimum Wage after controlling for time and area fixed effects, and labour market characteristics. For both TTWAs with high (above-median) and low (below-median) labour market concentration, employment is negatively related to the National Minimum Wage “bite? (that is, how many individuals in each labour market are affected by the National Minimum Wage). However, this relationship is weaker in more concentrated labour markets. ![](images/57a8bfc5e664df18fd671b7e84bffaf0513b0d29b161de042422737eb69a1833.jpg) Figure 11: In concentrated labour markets, minimum wages decrease employment by less Notes: Scatterplot of TTWA total employment against the share of individuals affected by the National Minimum Wage, by above- and belowmedian labour market concentration, from ASHE, Great Britain, 2014-21. Source:CMA(2024). Since the relevant labour-market outcomes for this analysis are only observed at the TTWA level in the data the report uses, the analysis cannot control for individual worker characteristics. Therefore, additional caution needs to be taken in interpreting these results. Evidence on the wider economic impact of labour market power is still in its infancy. An emerging literature at the intersection of industrial organization and macroeconomics has tried to quantify the welfare and productivity impacts of labour market power (De Loecker et al., 2021; Deb et al., 2022; Berger et al., 2022). These papers generally find sizeable aggregate impacts of labour market power, at least for the US. The evidence on consumer impacts is even thinner on the ground. We note, but sidestep entirely, the issue of labour market consequences of product market power. Recent work by Montag (2023) provides estimates of the trade-off this may create between consumer and worker interests in international mergers, using the example of the recent Maytag/Whirlpool merger.32 But more work clearly needs to be done. ### V. Why has UK labour market power fallen, and what does this mean for policy? For the UK, the CMA report shows that despite stable labour market concentration, UK wage markdowns and the wage-concentration penalty have both fallen in recent decades, suggesting that market power has shifted away from firms and towards workers. What can explain this shift in labour market power? The literature offers broadly three theories. First, it is possible that institutions that create countervailing worker power have risen in prominence, for instance if unions have gained strength or collective bargaining has become more widespread. This is essentially the reverse of what Farber et al. (2021) and Naidu (2022) argue has happened to the US over the twentieth century. Second, other labour market policies, such as the National Minimum Wage, could have strengthened the hand of workers. This would be consistent with findings about minimum wage increases elsewhere (Cengiz et al., 2019; Dube et al., 2022). Finally, general labour market conditions could have changed, shifting power towards workers (as argued for the US by Autor et al., 2023). Figure 12 shows some tentative evidence on the likelihood of these three theories from the CMA report. Panel 1 plots trade union membership and collective bargaining coverage over the last two decades. As in other comparable countries (Farber et al., 2021), both have fallen slightly in recent decades. Panel 2 plots the incidence of the National Minimum Wage for low-concentration, medium-concentration, and high-concentration labour markets. The National Minimum Wage has indeed expanded significantly, but mostly in low- and medium-concentration labour markets. Finally, Panel 3 plots the UK's labour force participation ratio, a measure of general labour market tightness. Labour markets in the UK are tight by international comparison (OECD, 2022) and labour market tightness has increased further in the past two decades. While more research is needed, together the three panels suggest that general labour market policies are the most likely factor behind the shift in UK labour market power from firms to workers. If true, this finding underscores that in labour markets (unlike in product markets) other policy institutions besides competition agencies may have more effective tools to address market power. ### V. Open questions for further research This paper has surveyed the recent increase in labour market-focused competition interventions and set out the current state of research on labour market power. As emphasized in the introduction, we have focused on the impact of labour market power on workers but have largely sidestepped the impact of labour market power on consumers, or product market power on worker outcomes. Important open questions remain, however. In this section, we highlight four important classes of questions: those related to our theoretical understanding of how labour market power operates; those related to the empirical ubiquity of certain practices, and the strength of their effects; those related to the legal toolbox to address competition issues in labour markets; and the normative questions inherent in the existing empirical trade-offs. A frst set of questions is theoretical. Researchers have used monopsony, search, and bargaining based models to think about labour market power (Manning, 2011; Manning, 2021). Each may be useful for understanding aspects of imperfectly competitive labour markets but may also come with subtly different empirical predictions and welfare implications. The monopsony model for imperfectly competitive labour markets states that the monopsonist restricts how much labour it employs, allowing the firm to suppress wages to maximize profts. This is analogous to a monopolist reducing its output to raise prices above the otherwise ^competitive’ level. In a world where the firm has market power in both output and labour markets, the so-called 'monemporist' (Nichol, 1943) has dual incentives to shrink its input demand, putting downwards pressure on wages and lowering social welfare.33 In contrast, in many search and bargaining models, labour market power does not necessarily impact the equilibrium quantity of labour, but merely shifts surplus from workers to frms. In a world described by those models, welfare concerns around labour market power are therefore primarily about workers, not consumers. Beyond the basic model selection question, there are other theoretical questions that would benefit from further scrutiny. For instance, what is the static and dynamic impact of labour market power on consumer and aggregate welfare? What parameters does this depend on? And how does labour market power influence the incentives of firms that have it (and those that do not)? For instance, how might it influence innovation and directed technological change? Does it matter for (consumer) welfare? Even with a suitable model identified, empirical questions need answering. These fall into two categories: first are descriptive statements of fact. How common is wage fixing? How common are no-poach agreements? Has the geography of labour markets changed with recent technological advances? Second are statements about causal relationships. What is the labour market impact of mergers? What is the impact of rising market power under rent-sharing? How restrictive are restrictive covenants? And how do non-competes affect innovation on balance? Figure 13 ilustrates the importance of even the descriptive statements of facts across two panels: the first shows the correlation between industry-level product market power under the assumption that materials markets are more competitive than labour markets. The second shows the correlation for the opposite assumption. The correlation in Panel 1 is negative: industries with more market power in output markets have less market power in labour markets. In Panel 2, the correlation is positive: industries with more market power in output markets also have more market power in labour markets. ![](images/f2a6a5b64bb41dbf3162e1d42719ca67a29b45c9a4760ef687a3281ee2d6c4ef.jpg) Data from Labour Force Survey. ![](images/8bd927cb038d2c266561a046cd00dfbeb829304bd9e8e8fe9d088b558e13c703.jpg) Data from Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings(ASHE), 2002 - 2022. Assuming relatively more competitive materials markets or competitive labour markets yield opposing results. Of course, in practice neither will be fully frictionless: while this paper has focused on labour market power, an emerging literature documents market power in input markets (Morlacco, 2019; Rubens, 2023; Hahn, 2023). Mechanically, the reason this assumption matters for the empirical findings is because it determines which input is used to compute price markups. Theoretically, market power in output and labour markets need not be correlated: a firm may be a locally important employer but sell on a globally competitive product market. Conversely, a firm with product market power may be located in a dense labour market with many other opportunities for its employees. Some recent evidence even suggests that in some settings, where bargaining arrangements are strong, firms may share monopoly rents with workers (Treuren, 2022), consistent with a negative relationship between market power in labour and product markets. Further research is needed to answer which of these two identifying assumptions is more likely valid, and therefore whether labour market power and product market power are generally found in the same firms or not. If market power or other frictions are present in both input markets, both markup and markdown estimates may be affected. Once the theoretical and empirical connections are clear, this leaves the policy question of what tools competition agencies have at their disposal, and what tools they might need to effectively address labour market power. As this article sets out, existing actions in this area mostly take the form of investigations of wage fixing and no-poach agreements, collusive behaviour that in many jurisdictions is illegal, or the issuance of guidance. While Marinescu and Hovenkamp (2019) make the case that, in the US, there exists well-established legal doctrine to block mergers on input market grounds, this is not universally the case for other jurisdictions. What tools do competition agencies therefore have already, and what tools are needed to address labour market power? In some jurisdictions, other policy-makers may have better or at least complementary tools. In the UK, for instance, the Department for Work and Pensions, the Department for Business and Trade, the Low Pay Commission, and HM Treasury all arguably set some policies that can affect labour market power. Finally, even with complete clarity about these theoretical, empirical, and legal questions, some complex normative questions remain for further research. Among the questions labour market power raises are: should the interests of workers be considered where they conflict with the interests of consumers? How about workers and other input suppliers? Even where these conflicts are absent, how should competition agencies trade off the interests of different types of workers? Non-competes are particularly prevalent among high-income and white-collar employees (CMA, 2024). Given regulators limited resources, should they be prioritized over other forms of labour market power that perhaps are more widespread or disproportionately fall on low-income workers? In the background loom broader questions of democratic legitimacy and institutional design (Tinbergen, 1952; Dewatripont and Tirole, 1999; Tirole, 2023). After a few quiet decades, both research and competition authorities? thinking on labour market power are evolving at a rapid pace. This presents the opportunity of addressing previously unaddressed harms, but also means that practice risks outrunning the current state of the evidence. We hope that the coming years bring further clarity on the four sets of open questions we outline in this paper. ## References Abel, W., Tenreyro, S., and Thwaites, G. # Trade Liberalization and Labor Monopsony: Evidence from Chinese Firms Illenin Kondo\* Yao Amber Lit Wei Qian+ Minneapolis Fed HKUST SHUFE April 12, 2021 ## Abstract This paper studies the impact of trade liberalization on firms’ labor market monopsony power. Using firm-level data and variations in tariff reductions across industries in China, we find that input tariff liberalization is associated with lower labor markdowns across firms. We further document that these pro-competitive labor market effects are more pronounced for skill-intensive firms. Finally, we show that skill-intensive frms reduce markdowns much less in areas experiencing a larger increase in skilled labor supply measured using college expansion. Overall, our results suggest labor market power may be an important margin of adjustment to trade. JEL: E2, F1, J2, J3, J42 Keywords: Trade liberalization, labor market power, skill intensity, China. # 1 Introduction How does trade liberalization affect the labor market power of firms? Even though the labor markets effects of trade liberalization are extensively studied, the literature typically abstracts from labor monopsony. As a result, little is known about the impact of trade liberalization on the exercise of monopsony power against labor, and its underlying mechanism. In this paper, we document trade-induced labor markdowns in China. An emerging literature studies the impact of trade policy on firm markup strategies in the product market (e.g., De Loecker, Goldberg, Khandelwal, and Pavcnik, 2016 for India; Fan, Gao, Li and Tuan, 2018 for China). Growing product market concentration, rising inequality, and declining labor's share of income have led to renewed interest in the consequences of product market power as well as pro-competitive policies. Trade liberalization is in fact a commonly proposed pro-competitive policy (see for example Edmond, Midrigan and Xu 2015), and the rising threat of protectionism may well be anti-competitive. We conduct an empirical analysis of the impact of trade policy on labor market power based on Chinese firm-level data. China is an especially interesting case for multiple reasons. First, it is the largest economy in the world in PPP (purchasing power parity) terms with the largest labor force (twice as large as the U.S. and E.U. combined). Moreover, it is one of the world's largest importers and exporters. Second, China unilaterally liberalized toward the rest of the world in 2001 as part of its joining the WTO, a policy experiment we will utilize. Third, labor's share in China is quite low, standing at roughly 40 percent of value-added in manufacturing in 2001 and declining since. Finally, the nature of China's labor market fexibility is disputed. Many have viewed persistent low wages during the remarkable industrialization in China as the result of a Lewis (1954)- like, elastically supplied surplus labor from the rural sector (e.g, Storesletten, Zhao and Zillibotti, 2019). At the same time, however, the well-known Houkou registration system restricts internal migration across regions, and the college expansion since late 1990s also provides a quasi-natural experiment to well test the mechanism at work for skill heterogeneity in labor market. Globally, China faces competition from lower wage upstart countries like Vietnam. In practice, evaluating monopsony power in labor market starts with measuring labor markdowns, the wedge between the value of the marginal product of labor and the wage. Lacking direct data on wages and the marginal product of labor, we utilize the methods of Brooks, Kaboski, Li, and Qian (2021), who show the markdown can be measured as the ratio of the de Loecker and Warzynski (2012) markup measured using labor as the input (i.e., the ratio of the elasticity of revenue with respect to labor over the share of revenue that labor is paid) over the true markup (measured using a price-taking input, for example, material). The estimates show that markdowns are considerable in Chinese manufacturing. To examine the impact of trade liberalization on labor market power, we employ several data sources. First, China's panel data set on manufacturing firms, the Annual Survey of Chinese Industrial Enterprises (CIE), covers all state-owned enterprises (SOEs), and non-state-owned enterprises with annual sales of at least 5 million RMB (about \$750,000 in 2008). The required data are available from 1999-2008 (with the hope to update to more recent years) and can be used to estimate markdowns at the firm (establishment) level. Second, tariff data at the industry level is then run through the input-output matrices to also yield tariffs on intermediates at the industry level. These data can be multiplied by the initial labor force mix to yield an initial local labor market exposure to the liberalization that varies across region. Third, we utilize household level data on hukou registrations to get region-specific measures of internal migrants from the 2000 and 2010 Censuses. Fourth, we use data on exports to distinguish exporting firms from non-exporting, and also distinguishing the intensity of exporting. Finally, we use the education information for workers from the 2004 census data to compute the skill intensity across firms, and college expansion information at the regional level to serve as exogenous shock to skilled labor supply. The liberalization episode involves both time and industry variation. The liberalization was sudden, involving a sharp and sudden cut in tariff rates in 2001. It reduced tariffs from high and variable across industries to much lower levels with much less variance. Thus, the liberalization disproportionately impacted industries that were initially high tariff and the initial tariff level interacted with a post-2001 dummy as an instrument is a plausibly exogenous instrument for industry level tariff variations. Moreover, preexisting industrial variation over regions lead to regional variation in the impact on labor markets. We then perform regression analysis on the firm-level markups and markdowns with respect to input and output tariffs. We document three findings. First, after joining the WTO, reductions in input tariffs were associated with lower markdowns, pointing to the importance of input trade liberalization on labor market power. Second, the decline in labor markdown after trade liberalization is more pronounced for skill-intensive firms compared to non skill-intensive firms. Third, to further test the skill intensive results, we use the exogenous shock to the supply of skilled labor in China through regional variations of college expansion in China. The results confirm that the difference in the markdown responses across firms' skill intensity becomes smaller in regions that experience college expansion and thus have an increase in skilled labor supply. To alleviate the concern that the declining markdowns are resulting from increased product markups after trade liberalization, we further conduct two exercises as robustness checks. First, we show that our main results of reduced markdowns and the heterogeneity effect across firms skill intensity are robust to controlling for lagged markups. Second, and more importantly, we show that the role of skill intensity on trade-induced lower markdowns is not present for trade-induced product markups. Related Literature Our paper relates broadly to three strands of literature: the literature on monopsony power in labor markets, the literature on trade and labor market outcomes, and the literature on trade liberalization and product markups. A growing number of papers investigate labor monopsony, especially in the United States (Card et al., 2018; Gouin-Bonenfant, 2018; Lamadon, Mogstad and Setzler, 2017; Berger, Herkenhoff and Mongey, 2018; Hershbein, Macaluso and Yeh, 2020). We borrow our measure for markdowns on labor from Brooks et al. (2021) and Brooks et al. (2020), which also focus on labor markdown in India and China. This paper contributes to this literature by looking at the impact of trade liberalization on firms’ labor monopsony power,however. The trade literature has extensively evaluated the labor markets effects of trade liberalization on wages, employment, and inequality (Davidson and Matusz, 2004; Amiti and Davis, 2012; Topalova, 2010; Goldberg and Pavcnik, 2007). Recently, the dramatic rise of China's importance in international trade has motivated a vibrant literature on the labor markets effects on trade-induced foreign competition. (David, Dorn and Hanson, 2013; Pierce and Schott, 2016; Kondo, 2018; Caliendo, Dvorkin and Parro, 2019). In contrast to the existing literature, we allow for labor market power. This departure allows us to isolate one potentially-important determinant of both measured wages and employment: the effects of trade on labor markdowns. Our findings also suggest that labor monopsony power can infuence the skill premium when trade-induced markdowns vary with firms' skill intensity. Our paper also relates to the literature on the competitive effects of trade liberalization in product markets. Edmond, Midrigan and Xu (2015) and Arkolakis et al. (2019) provide theoretical and quantitative insights on the competitive effects of trade in the presence of variable markups. Goldberg et al. (2010) pioneered a growing literature on the effects of input tariff reductions on firm performance measured by product scope and new product. More recent studies examined the impact of trade liberalization on firm markup (e.g., de Loecker et al. (2016) for India, and Fan et al. (2018) for China). We build on this literature and estimate markdowns as the ratio of the labor-based markup to the materials-based markup. We show that our results are not mechanically due to changes in product markups. Specifically, we show the heterogeneous effects of skill intensity on tradeinduced markdowns are absent for product markups. # 2 Data and Measurement ## 2.1 Firm-level Production and Tariff Data The main dataset used in the analysis is the firm-level production data from the Annual Survey of Chinese Industrial Enterprises (CIE). The CIE data is conducted by the National Bureau of Statistics of China, and it covers all state-owned enterprises (SOEs), and non-state-owned enterprises with annual sales of at least 5 million RMB (about \$760,000 in 2020). Between 2000 and 2006, the number of frms in the CIE data grows from approximately 162,000 to 300,000. The variation in the number of firms across years necessitates that we use an unbalanced panel in our analysis. We focus only on the manufacturing sector and 4-digit manufacturing industries. We construct real output, real capital stocks, and real intermediate input by defating the nominal values using defators at 2-digit industries from China? National Bureau of Statistics and a 1998 base year. One limitation of the CIE data is that it covers dis-proportionally larger firms. Since larger firms tend to have higher productivity, the CIE data covers about 76 percent of aggregate manufacturing gross output in China, but only about 37-43 percent of the overall employment in manufacturing.1 The omission of smaller firms in the CIE data precludes us from speaking to their behavior. The tariff data come from the World Trade Organization (WTO) website. We map the tariff data at the 8-digit harmonized system (HS) product level into 3-digit input/output (IO) industry classification based on the HS codes and the China's 2002 IO table. Our 3- digit output tariffs are just the simple average of all tariffs that fall into the corresponding category of the 3-digit IO industry code. We compute 3-digit input tariffs as an input-cost weighted average of output tariffs: $$ \tau_{i t}^{\mathrm{{input}}}=\sum_{k}\alpha_{k i}\tau_{k t}^{\mathrm{{output}}} $$ where Tkt $\tau_{k t}^{\mathrm{output}}$ is the 3-digit output trifs imposed on industry $k$ at time $t$ , and $\alpha_{k i}$ is the percentage of industry $i$ 's total costs that were expended on products supplied by industry $k$ as intermediate inputs for industry $i$ . Finally, we map IO 3-digit tariffs into the 4-digit Chinese Industrial Classification (CIC) code system so that we can merge it with our firm-level production data. ## 2.2 Measuring Markups To construct measures of markups, we adopt the approach suggested by de Loecker and Warzynski (2012), which is build upon the insights from Hall (1987). de Locker and Warzynski show that the markup for firm i at time $\mathrm{t}$ can be expressed as $$ \mu_{i t}=\frac{\theta_{i t}^{M}}{\alpha_{i t}^{M}} $$ where $M$ indicates any fexible-chosen, price-taking input. $\theta_{i t}$ is the output elasticity on input $M$ and $\alpha_{i t}$ is the share of output revenue spent on input $M$ .We follow the IO literature and assume materials as the fexible-chosen inputs. We compute the factor payment share $\alpha_{i t}$ directly using our production data since the data contains detailed firm-level information, including gross output and material expenditure.2 To estimate the output elasticity of materials, We use the production function estimation of Ackerberg, Caves and Frazer (2015) as in de Loecker and Warzynski (2012). First, we estimate a polynominal regression of logged output and obtain a non-parametric estimate of logged output free of measurement error. Then, we construct measures of productivity under the assumption of a 3rd-order translog specification of gross output. Finally, we estimate all coefficients in the production function by relying on the law of motion for productivity. The output elasticity of materials is computed based on the estimated coefficients of the production function. Although the above approach for estimating markups is standard in the IO literature (see de Loecker and Eeckhout, 2017; Hershbein, Macaluso and Yeh, 2020; Brooks et al., 2021), it has some important shortcomings. First, this approach assumes that the production function is constant for all firms within an industry and only differs by a factor-neutral productivity parameter. Second, the identification of the production function relies on the assumptions that preclude the estimation of the output elasticity of materials, which is necessary to apply the de Loecker and Warzynski (2012) formula. In light of the shortcomings in the standard approach of estimating markups, we tested our baseline results using two alternative estimates of markups. In the first alternative approach, w estimate markups using the goss proft margin, which is computed as $\frac{\mathrm{sales}}{\mathrm{costs}}$ The gross profit margin is a valid estimate of the markup if the production function is constant returns to scale and the firm is price-taking in its inputs.3 The second alternative approach assumes that the production function is Cobb-Douglas with respect to materials. Under this strong assumption, the output elasticity of materials is constant for all firms, and we choose $\theta^{M}=0.8$ so that the average markup from using this approach equals the average measured using the gross profit margin method. ## 2.3 Measuring Markdowns This subsection describes the steps we take to construct measurements of markdowns. First, we compute the ratio of the labor-based markup to the materials-based markup. The equation can be expressed as $$ \frac{\mu_{i t}^{L}}{\mu_{i t}^{M}}=\frac{\theta_{i t}^{L}}{\alpha_{i t}^{L}}\cdot\frac{\alpha_{i t}^{M}}{\theta_{i t}^{M}} $$ where $\alpha_{i t}^{L}$ and $\alpha_{i t}^{M}$ represent the factor payment share for labor and materials, and $\theta_{i t}^{L}$ and $\theta_{i t}^{M}$ represent the output elasticities. Normally, $\frac{\mu_{i t}^{L}}{\mu_{i t}^{M}}$ represents any unnamed distortion on labor relative to materials. Our assumption that materials is fexibly chosen implies that threnfe a L identifies only distortion to labor. Second, we follow Brooks et al. (2021) and interpret the comovement of $\frac{\mu_{i t}^{L}}{\mu_{i t}^{M}}$ witha frm's market share as the exercise of the monopsony power in the labor market. Specifically, we estimate the following equation $$ \frac{\mu_{i t}^{L}}{\mu_{i t}^{M}}=\Gamma_{t}+\delta_{i}+\beta s_{i t}^{L}+\epsilon_{i t} $$ where st = ietule denotes the firm $i$ 's share in the labor market $l$ at time $i$ . We rescale the ratio $\frac{\mu_{i t}^{L}}{\mu_{i t}^{M}}$ so that the average intercept in the equation (1) is 1. Rescaling assures us that eliminating the market power in the labor market (i.e., the component of this markdown that covaries with labor market share) is equivalent to setting the average markdown to one. The final step of computing markdowns requires us to define the appropriate labor market for computing firm's labor market share. We consider labor markets to be segmented both geographically and by type of work. Geographically, we think provinces are appropriate choices for the labor market since the cross-province migration in China is restricted by the Hukou system. Regarding the type of work, we assume workers have a degree of specialization and hence cannot move perfectly across 4-digit industries. To further test the underlying mechanism, we now turn to an exogenous shock to the supply of skilled labor in China - college expansion that started since the late 1990s. Recall that the markdown is measured as the ratio of two markups: the labor-based markup and the true markup. Therefore, an increase in the true markup would mechanically cause a decrease in our measured markdown. In this subsection, we present three results that address the concern that our results on input liberalization and markdowns arise from a mechanical effect of tariffs on product markups. First, we test whether our baseline results about the effect of input trade liberalization on markdowns are robust to controlling for markups. But controlling for contemporaneous markups in the regression is problematic because markup also responds to changes in tariffs (see the discussion of “bad controls" in Angrist and Pischke, 2009.) Therefore, we include one-period lagged log markups as controls in the regression. Table 5 shows that controlling for lagged markups has little impact on the estimated coefficients in the regressions. Input trade liberalization continues to have a significant negative effect on markdowns even after controlling for lagged markups.
